100%;\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eH2O is an in-memory platform for distributed, scalable machine learning. H2O uses familiar interfaces like R, Python, Scala, Java, JSON and the Flow notebook/web interface, and works seamlessly with big data technologies like Hadoop and Spark. H2O provides implementations of many popular \u003ca href=\"http://docs.h2o.ai/h2o/latest-stable/h2o-docs/data-science.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ealgorithms\u003c/a\u003e such as Generalized Linear Models (GLM), Gradient Boosting Machines (including XGBoost), Random Forests, Deep Neural Networks, Stacked Ensembles, Naive Bayes, Generalized Additive Models (GAM), Cox Proportional Hazards, K-Means, PCA, Word2Vec, as well as a fully automatic machine learning algorithm (\u003ca href=\"http://docs.h2o.ai/h2o/latest-stable/h2o-docs/automl.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eH2O AutoML\u003c/a\u003e).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eH2O is extensible so that developers can add data transformations and custom algorithms of their choice and access them through all of those clients.  H2O models can be \u003ca href=\"http://docs.h2o.ai/h2o/latest-stable/h2o-docs/save-and-load-model.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003edownloaded\u003c/a\u003e and loaded into H2O memory for scoring, or exported into POJO or MOJO format for extemely fast scoring in \u003ca href=\"http://docs.h2o.ai/h2o/latest-stable/h2o-docs/productionizing.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eproduction\u003c/a\u003e.  More information can be found in the \u003ca href=\"http://docs.h2o.ai/h2o/latest-stable/h2o-docs/index.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eH2O User Guide\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eH2O-3 (this repository) is the third incarnation of H2O, and the successor to \u003ca href=\"https://github.com/h2oai/h2o-2\"\u003eH2O-2\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv build\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cblockquote\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eNotes\u003c/strong\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRunning tests starts five test JVMs that form an H2O cluster and requires at least 8GB of RAM (preferably 16GB of RAM).\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRunning \u003ccode\u003e./gradlew syncRPackages\u003c/code\u003e is supported on Windows, OS X, and Linux, and is strongly recommended but not required. \u003ccode\u003e./gradlew syncRPackages\u003c/code\u003e ensures a complete and consistent environment with pre-approved versions of the packages required for tests and builds. The packages can be installed manually, but we recommend setting an ENV variable and using \u003ccode\u003e./gradlew syncRPackages\u003c/code\u003e. To set the ENV variable, use the following format (where `${WORKSPACE} can be any path):\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"mkdir -p ${WORKSPACE}/Rlibrary\nexport R_LIBS_USER=${WORKSPACE}/Rlibrary\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003emkdir -p ${WORKSPACE}/Rlibrary\nexport R_LIBS_USER=${WORKSPACE}/Rlibrary\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/blockquote\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eWe recommend using \u003ccode\u003e./gradlew clean\u003c/code\u003e after each \u003ccode\u003egit pull\u003c/code\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eSkip tests by adding \u003ccode\u003e-x test\u003c/code\u003e at the end the gradle build command line.  Tests typically run for 7-10 minutes on a Macbook Pro laptop with 4 CPUs (8 hyperthreads) and 16 GB of RAM.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eSyncing smalldata is not required after each pull, but if tests fail due to missing data files, then try \u003ccode\u003e./gradlew syncSmalldata\u003c/code\u003e as the first troubleshooting step.  Syncing smalldata downloads data files from AWS S3 to the smalldata directory in your workspace.  The sync is incremental.  Do not check in these files.  The smalldata directory is in .gitignore.  If you do not run any tests, you do not need the smalldata directory.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eRunning \u003ccode\u003e./gradlew syncRPackages\u003c/code\u003e is supported on Windows, OS X, and Linux, and is strongly recommended but not required. \u003ccode\u003e./gradlew syncRPackages\u003c/code\u003e ensures a complete and consistent environment with pre-approved versions of the packages required for tests and builds. The packages can be installed manually, but we recommend setting an ENV variable and using \u003ccode\u003e./gradlew syncRPackages\u003c/code\u003e. To set the ENV variable, use the following format (where \u003ccode\u003e${WORKSPACE}\u003c/code\u003e can be any path):\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"mkdir -p ${WORKSPACE}/Rlibrary\nexport R_LIBS_USER=${WORKSPACE}/Rlibrary\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003emkdir -p ${WORKSPACE}/Rlibrary\nexport R_LIBS_USER=${WORKSPACE}/Rlibrary\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch4 tabindex=\"-1\" \u0026gt;\u0026gt; /etc/yum.conf\nsudo yum -y update\n\nsudo yum -y install R R-devel git python-pip openssl-devel libxml2-devel libcurl-devel gcc gcc-c++ make openssl-devel kernel-devel texlive texinfo texlive-latex-fonts libX11-devel mesa-libGL-devel mesa-libGL nodejs npm python-devel numpy scipy python-pandas\n\nsudo pip install scikit-learn grip tabulate statsmodels wheel\n\nmkdir ~/Rlibrary\nexport JAVA_HOME=/opt/jdk1.7.0_79\nexport JRE_HOME=/opt/jdk1.7.0_79/jre\nexport PATH=$PATH:/opt/jdk1.7.0_79/bin:/opt/jdk1.7.0_79/jre/bin\nexport R_LIBS_USER=~/Rlibrary\n\n# install local R packages\nR -e 'install.packages(c(\u0026quot;RCurl\u0026quot;,\u0026quot;jsonlite\u0026quot;,\u0026quot;statmod\u0026quot;,\u0026quot;devtools\u0026quot;,\u0026quot;roxygen2\u0026quot;,\u0026quot;testthat\u0026quot;), dependencies=TRUE, repos=\u0026quot;http://cran.rstudio.com/\u0026quot;)'\n\ncd\ngit clone https://github.com/h2oai/h2o-3.git\ncd h2o-3\n\n# Build H2O\n./gradlew syncSmalldata\n./gradlew syncRPackages\n./gradlew build -x test\n\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003ecd /opt\nsudo wget --no-cookies --no-check-certificate --header \"Cookie: gpw_e24=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.oracle.com%2F; /etc/yum.conf\nsudo yum -y update\n\nsudo yum -y install R R-devel git python-pip openssl-devel libxml2-devel libcurl-devel gcc gcc-c++ make openssl-devel kernel-devel texlive texinfo texlive-latex-fonts libX11-devel mesa-libGL-devel mesa-libGL nodejs npm python-devel numpy scipy python-pandas\n\nsudo pip install scikit-learn grip tabulate statsmodels wheel\n\nmkdir ~/Rlibrary\nexport JAVA_HOME=/opt/jdk1.7.0_79\nexport JRE_HOME=/opt/jdk1.7.0_79/jre\nexport PATH=$PATH:/opt/jdk1.7.0_79/bin:/opt/jdk1.7.0_79/jre/bin\nexport R_LIBS_USER=~/Rlibrary\n\n# install local R packages\nR -e 'install.packages(c(\"RCurl\",\"jsonlite\",\"statmod\",\"devtools\",\"roxygen2\",\"testthat\"), dependencies=TRUE, repos=\"http://cran.rstudio.com/\")'\n\ncd\ngit clone https://github.com/h2oai/h2o-3.git\ncd h2o-3\n\n# Build H2O\n./gradlew syncSmalldata\n./gradlew syncRPackages\n./gradlew build -x test\n\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca name=\"user-content-launching\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e5. Launching H2O after Building\" href=\"#5-launching-h2o-after-building\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTo start the H2O cluster locally, execute the following on the command line:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"java -jar build/h2o.jar\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003ejava -jar build/h2o.jar\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eA list of available start-up JVM and H2O options (e.g. \u003ccode\u003e-Xmx\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003e-nthreads\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003e-ip\u003c/code\u003e), is available in the \u003ca href=\"http://docs.h2o.ai/h2o/latest-stable/h2o-docs/starting-h2o.html#from-the-command-line\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eH2O User Guide\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca name=\"user-content-buildinghadoop\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e6. Building H2O on Hadoop\u003c/h2\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-6-building-h2o-on-hadoop\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: 6. Building H2O on Hadoop\" href=\"#6-building-h2o-on-hadoop\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ePre-built H2O-on-Hadoop zip files are available on the \u003ca href=\"http://h2o.ai/download\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003edownload page\u003c/a\u003e.  Each Hadoop distribution version has a separate zip file in h2o-3.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTo build H2O with Hadoop support yourself, first install sphinx for python: \u003ccode\u003epip install sphinx\u003c/code\u003e\nThen start the build by entering  the following from the top-level h2o-3 directory:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"export BUILD_HADOOP=1;\n./gradlew build -x test;\n./gradlew dist;\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003eexport BUILD_HADOOP=1;\n./gradlew build -x test;\n./gradlew dist;\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThis will create a directory called 'target' and generate zip files there.  Note that \u003ccode\u003eBUILD_HADOOP\u003c/code\u003e is the default behavior when the username is \u003ccode\u003ejenkins\u003c/code\u003e (refer to \u003ccode\u003esettings.gradle\u003c/code\u003e); otherwise you have to request it, as shown above.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTo build the zip files only for selected distributions use the \u003ccode\u003eH2O_TARGET\u003c/code\u003e env variable together with \u003ccode\u003eBUILD_HADOOP\u003c/code\u003e, for example:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"export BUILD_HADOOP=1;\nexport H2O_TARGET=hdp2.5,hdp2.6\n./gradlew build -x test;\n./gradlew dist;\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003eexport BUILD_HADOOP=1;\nexport H2O_TARGET=hdp2.5,hdp2.6\n./gradlew build -x test;\n./gradlew dist;\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eAdding support for a new version of Hadoop\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-adding-support-for-a-new-version-of-hadoop\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Adding support for a new version of Hadoop\" href=\"#adding-support-for-a-new-version-of-hadoop\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIn the \u003ccode\u003eh2o-hadoop\u003c/code\u003e directory, each Hadoop version has a build directory for the driver and an assembly directory for the fatjar.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eYou need to:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd a new driver directory and assembly directory (each with a \u003ccode\u003ebuild.gradle\u003c/code\u003e file) in \u003ccode\u003eh2o-hadoop\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd these new projects to \u003ccode\u003eh2o-3/settings.gradle\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd the new Hadoop version to \u003ccode\u003eHADOOP_VERSIONS\u003c/code\u003e in \u003ccode\u003emake-dist.sh\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAdd the new Hadoop version to the list in \u003ccode\u003eh2o-dist/buildinfo.json\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eSecure user impersonation\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-secure-user-impersonation\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Secure user impersonation\" href=\"#secure-user-impersonation\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eHadoop supports \u003ca href=\"https://hadoop.apache.org/docs/r2.7.3/hadoop-project-dist/hadoop-common/Superusers.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003esecure user impersonation\u003c/a\u003e through its Java API.  A kerberos-authenticated user can be allowed to proxy any username that meets specified criteria entered in the NameNode's core-site.xml file.  This impersonation only applies to interactions with the Hadoop API or the APIs of Hadoop-related services that support it (this is not the same as switching to that user on the machine of origin).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eSetting up secure user impersonation (for h2o):\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eCreate or find an id to use as proxy which has limited-to-no access to HDFS or related services; the proxy user need only be used to impersonate a user\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e(Required if not using h2odriver) If you are not using the driver (e.g. you wrote your own code against h2o's API using Hadoop), make the necessary code changes to impersonate users (see \u003ca href=\"http://hadoop.apache.org/docs/r2.8.0/api/org/apache/hadoop/security/UserGroupInformation.html\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eorg.apache.hadoop.security.UserGroupInformation\u003c/a\u003e)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIn either of Ambari/Cloudera Manager or directly on the NameNode's core-site.xml file, add 2/3 properties for the user we wish to use as a proxy (replace  with the simple user name - not the fully-qualified principal name).\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003ehadoop.proxyuser.\u0026lt;proxyusername\u0026gt;.hosts\u003c/code\u003e: the hosts the proxy user is allowed to perform impersonated actions on behalf of a valid user from\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003ehadoop.proxyuser.\u0026lt;proxyusername\u0026gt;.groups\u003c/code\u003e: the groups an impersonated user must belong to for impersonation to work with that proxy user\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ccode\u003ehadoop.proxyuser.\u0026lt;proxyusername\u0026gt;.users\u003c/code\u003e: the users a proxy user is allowed to impersonate\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eExample: \u003ccode\u003e\u0026lt;property\u0026gt; \u0026lt;name\u0026gt;hadoop.proxyuser.myproxyuser.hosts\u0026lt;/name\u0026gt; \u0026lt;value\u0026gt;host1,host2\u0026lt;/value\u0026gt; \u0026lt;/property\u0026gt; \u0026lt;property\u0026gt; \u0026lt;name\u0026gt;hadoop.proxyuser.myproxyuser.groups\u0026lt;/name\u0026gt; \u0026lt;value\u0026gt;group1,group2\u0026lt;/value\u0026gt; \u0026lt;/property\u0026gt; \u0026lt;property\u0026gt; \u0026lt;name\u0026gt;hadoop.proxyuser.myproxyuser.users\u0026lt;/name\u0026gt; \u0026lt;value\u0026gt;user1,user2\u0026lt;/value\u0026gt; \u0026lt;/property\u0026gt;\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eRestart core services such as HDFS \u0026amp; YARN for the changes to take effect\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eImpersonated HDFS actions can be viewed in the hdfs audit log ('auth:PROXY' should appear in the \u003ccode\u003eugi=\u003c/code\u003e field in entries where this is applicable).  YARN similarly should show 'auth:PROXY' somewhere in the Resource Manager UI.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTo use secure impersonation with h2o's Hadoop driver:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eBefore this is attempted, see Risks with impersonation, below\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eWhen using the h2odriver (e.g. when running with \u003ccode\u003ehadoop jar ...\u003c/code\u003e), specify \u003ccode\u003e-principal \u0026lt;proxy user kerberos principal\u0026gt;\u003c/code\u003e, \u003ccode\u003e-keytab \u0026lt;proxy user keytab path\u0026gt;\u003c/code\u003e, and \u003ccode\u003e-run_as_user \u0026lt;hadoop username to impersonate\u0026gt;\u003c/code\u003e, in addition to any other arguments needed.  If the configuration was successful, the proxy user will log in and impersonate the \u003ccode\u003e-run_as_user\u003c/code\u003e as long as that user is allowed by either the users or groups configuration property (configured above); this is enforced by HDFS \u0026amp; YARN, not h2o's code.  The driver effectively sets its security context as the impersonated user so all supported Hadoop actions will be performed as that user (e.g. YARN, HDFS APIs support securely impersonated users, but others may not).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch4 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003ePrecautions to take when leveraging secure impersonation\u003c/h4\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-precautions-to-take-when-leveraging-secure-impersonation\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Precautions to take when leveraging secure impersonation\" href=\"#precautions-to-take-when-leveraging-secure-impersonation\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe target use case for secure impersonation is applications or services that pre-authenticate a user and then use (in this case) the h2odriver on behalf of that user.  H2O's Steam is a perfect example: auth user in web app over SSL, impersonate that user when creating the h2o YARN container.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe proxy user should have limited permissions in the Hadoop cluster; this means no permissions to access data or make API calls.  In this way, if it's compromised it would only have the power to impersonate a specific subset of the users in the cluster and only from specific machines.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eUse the \u003ccode\u003ehadoop.proxyuser.\u0026lt;proxyusername\u0026gt;.hosts\u003c/code\u003e property whenever possible or practical.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eDon't give the proxyusername's password or keytab to any user you don't want to impersonate another user (this is generally \u003cem\u003eany\u003c/em\u003e user).  The point of impersonation is not to allow users to impersonate each other.  See the first bullet for the typical use case.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eLimit user logon to the machine the proxying is occurring from whenever practical.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eMake sure the keytab used to login the proxy user is properly secured and that users can't login as that id (via \u003ccode\u003esu\u003c/code\u003e, for instance)\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eNever set hadoop.proxyuser..{users,groups} to '*' or 'hdfs', 'yarn', etc.  Allowing any user to impersonate hdfs, yarn, or any other important user/group should be done with extreme caution and \u003cem\u003estrongly\u003c/em\u003e analyzed before it's allowed.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch4 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eRisks with secure impersonation\u003c/h4\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-risks-with-secure-impersonation\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Risks with secure impersonation\" href=\"#risks-with-secure-impersonation\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe id performing the impersonation can be compromised like any other user id.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eSetting any \u003ccode\u003ehadoop.proxyuser.\u0026lt;proxyusername\u0026gt;.{hosts,groups,users}\u003c/code\u003e property to '*' can greatly increase exposure to security risk.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eWhen users aren't authenticated before being used with the driver (e.g. like Steam does via a secure web app/API), auditability of the process/system is difficult.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"$ git diff\ndiff --git project(\u0026quot;:h2o-algos\u0026quot;)\n   compile project(\u0026quot;:h2o-core\u0026quot;)\n   compile project(\u0026quot;:h2o-genmodel\u0026quot;)\n+  compile Sparkling Water\u003c/h2\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-7-sparkling-water\" class=\"anchor-element\" aria-label=\"Permalink: 7. Sparkling Water\" href=\"#7-sparkling-water\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eSparkling Water combines two open-source technologies: Apache Spark and the H2O Machine Learning platform.  It makes H2O’s library of advanced algorithms, including Deep Learning, GLM, GBM, K-Means, and Distributed Random Forest, accessible from Spark workflows. Spark users can select the best features from either platform to meet their Machine Learning needs.  Users can combine Spark's RDD API and Spark MLLib with H2O’s machine learning algorithms, or use H2O independently of Spark for the model building process and post-process the results in Spark.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSparkling Water Resources\u003c/strong\u003e:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul dir=\"auto\"\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"http://h2o.ai/download/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eDownload page for pre-built packages\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/h2oai/sparkling-water\"\u003eSparkling Water GitHub repository\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/h2oai/sparkling-water/blob/master/README.md\"\u003eREADME\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://github.com/h2oai/sparkling-water/blob/master/DEVEL.md\"\u003eDeveloper documentation\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca name=\"user-content-documentation\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e8. alt="Ask on Gitter" data-canonical-src="https://img.shields.io/gitter/room/h2oai/h2o-3?logo=gitter&logoColor=red&label=H2O%20chatroom&color=b5b5b5" style="max-width: 100%;"></a></p><p dir="auto">H2O is an in-memory platform for distributed, scalable machine learning. H2O uses familiar interfaces like R, Python, Scala, Java, JSON and the Flow notebook/web interface, and works seamlessly with big data technologies like Hadoop and Spark. H2O provides implementations of many popular <a href="http://docs.h2o.ai/h2o/latest-stable/h2o-docs/data-science.html" rel="nofollow">algorithms</a> such as Generalized Linear Models (GLM), Gradient Boosting Machines (including XGBoost), Random Forests, Deep Neural Networks, Stacked Ensembles, Naive Bayes, Generalized Additive Models (GAM), Cox Proportional Hazards, K-Means, PCA, Word2Vec, as well as a fully automatic machine learning algorithm (<a href="http://docs.h2o.ai/h2o/latest-stable/h2o-docs/automl.html" rel="nofollow">H2O AutoML</a>).</p><p dir="auto">H2O is extensible so that developers can add data transformations and custom algorithms of their choice and access them through all of those clients.  H2O models can be <a href="http://docs.h2o.ai/h2o/latest-stable/h2o-docs/save-and-load-model.html" rel="nofollow">downloaded</a> and loaded into H2O memory for scoring, or exported into POJO or MOJO format for extemely fast scoring in <a href="http://docs.h2o.ai/h2o/latest-stable/h2o-docs/productionizing.html" rel="nofollow">production</a>.  More information can be found in the <a href="http://docs.h2o.ai/h2o/latest-stable/h2o-docs/index.html" rel="nofollow">H2O User Guide</a>.</p><p dir="auto">H2O-3 (this repository) is the third incarnation of H2O, and the successor to <a href="https://github.com/h2oai/h2o-2">H2O-2</a>.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Table of There is also a <strong>Gitter</strong> H2O developer chat group, however for archival purposes & to maximize accessibility, we'd prefer that standard H2O Q&A be conducted on Stack Overflow.</p><p dir="auto"><a name="user-content-issuetracking"></a></p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">2.1 Issue Tracking and Feature Requests</h3><a id="user-content-21-issue-tracking-and-feature-requests" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: 2.1 Issue Tracking and Feature Requests" href="#21-issue-tracking-and-feature-requests"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">You can browse and create new issues in our GitHub repository:  <a href="https://github.com/h2oai/h2o-3">https://github.com/h2oai/h2o-3</a></p><ul dir="auto"><li>You can <strong>browse</strong> and search for <strong>issues</strong> without logging in to Github:<ol dir="auto"><li>Click the <code>Issues</code> tab on the top of the page</li><li>Apply filter to search for particular issues</li></ol></li><li>To <strong>create</strong> an <strong>issue</strong> (either a bug or a feature request):<ul dir="auto"><li>Create H2O-3 issues on the page <a href="https://github.com/h2oai/h2o-3/issues/new/choose">https://github.com/h2oai/h2o-3/issues/new/choose</a>. In particular, you can find Java artifacts in the maven/repo directory.</p><p dir="auto">Here is an example snippet of a gradle build file using h2o-3 as a dependency.  Replace x, y, z, and nnnn with valid numbers.</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="// h2o-3 dependency informationdef h2oBranch = 'master'def h2oBuildNumber = 'nnnn'def h2oProjectVersion = "x.y.z.${h2oBuildNumber}"repositories {  // h2o-3 dependencies  maven {    url "https://s3.amazonaws.com/h2o-release/h2o-3/${h2oBranch}/${h2oBuildNumber}/maven/repo/"  }}dependencies {  compile "ai.h2o:h2o-core:${h2oProjectVersion}"  compile "ai.h2o:h2o-algos:${h2oProjectVersion}"  compile "ai.h2o:h2o-web:${h2oProjectVersion}"  compile "ai.h2o:h2o-app:${h2oProjectVersion}"}"><pre class="notranslate"><code>// h2o-3 dependency informationdef h2oBranch = 'master'def h2oBuildNumber = 'nnnn'def h2oProjectVersion = "x.y.z.${h2oBuildNumber}"repositories {  // h2o-3 dependencies  maven {    url "https://s3.amazonaws.com/h2o-release/h2o-3/${h2oBranch}/${h2oBuildNumber}/maven/repo/"  }}dependencies {  compile "ai.h2o:h2o-core:${h2oProjectVersion}"  compile "ai.h2o:h2o-algos:${h2oProjectVersion}"  compile "ai.h2o:h2o-web:${h2oProjectVersion}"  compile "ai.h2o:h2o-app:${h2oProjectVersion}"}</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">Refer to the latest H2O-3 bleeding edge <a href="http://s3.amazonaws.com/h2o-release/h2o-3/master/latest.html" rel="nofollow">nightly build page</a> for information about installing nightly build artifacts.</p><p dir="auto">Refer to the <a href="https://github.com/h2oai/h2o-droplets">h2o-droplets GitHub repository</a> for a working example of how to use Java artifacts with gradle.</p><blockquote><p dir="auto">Note: Stable H2O-3 artifacts are periodically published to Maven Central (<a href="http://search.maven.org/#search%7Cga%7C1%7Cai.h2o" rel="nofollow">click here to search</a>) but may substantially lag behind H2O-3 Bleeding Edge nightly builds.</p></blockquote><p dir="auto"><a name="user-content-building"></a></p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" We use the Gradle wrapper (called <code>gradlew</code>) to ensure up-to-date local versions of Gradle and other dependencies are installed in your development directory.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">4.1. (preferably 16GB of RAM).</li><li>Running <code>./gradlew syncRPackages</code> is supported on Windows, OS X, and Linux, and is strongly recommended but not required. <code>./gradlew syncRPackages</code> ensures a complete and consistent environment with pre-approved versions of the packages required for tests and builds. The packages can be installed manually, but we recommend setting an ENV variable and using <code>./gradlew syncRPackages</code>. To set the ENV variable, use the following format (where `${WORKSPACE} can be any path):</li></ul><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="mkdir -p ${WORKSPACE}/Rlibraryexport R_LIBS_USER=${WORKSPACE}/Rlibrary"><pre class="notranslate"><code>mkdir -p ${WORKSPACE}/Rlibraryexport R_LIBS_USER=${WORKSPACE}/Rlibrary</code></pre></div></blockquote><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h4 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Recipe 3:  Pull, clean, build, and run <code>./gradlew clean</code> after each <code>git pull</code>.</p></li><li><p dir="auto">Skip tests by adding <code>-x test</code> at the end the gradle build command line.  Tests typically run for 7-10 minutes on a Macbook Pro laptop with 4 CPUs (8 hyperthreads) and 16 GB of RAM.</p></li><li><p dir="auto">Syncing smalldata is not required after each pull, but if tests fail due to missing data files, then try <code>./gradlew syncSmalldata</code> as the first troubleshooting step.  Syncing smalldata downloads data files from AWS S3 to the smalldata directory in your workspace.  The sync is incremental.  Do not check in these files.  The smalldata directory is in .gitignore.  If you do not run any tests, you do not need the smalldata directory.</p></li><li><p dir="auto">Running <code>./gradlew syncRPackages</code> is supported on Windows, OS X, and Linux, and is strongly recommended but not required. <code>./gradlew syncRPackages</code> ensures a complete and consistent environment with pre-approved versions of the packages required for tests and builds. The packages can be installed manually, but we recommend setting an ENV variable and using <code>./gradlew syncRPackages</code>. To set the ENV variable, use the following format (where <code>${WORKSPACE}</code> can be any path):</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="mkdir -p ${WORKSPACE}/Rlibraryexport R_LIBS_USER=${WORKSPACE}/Rlibrary"><pre class="notranslate"><code>mkdir -p ${WORKSPACE}/Rlibraryexport Launching H2O after Building" href="#5-launching-h2o-after-building"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">To start the H2O cluster locally, execute the following on the command line:</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="java -jar build/h2o.jar"><pre class="notranslate"><code>java -jar build/h2o.jar</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">A list of available start-up JVM and H2O options (e.g. <code>-Xmx</code>, <code>-nthreads</code>, <code>-ip</code>), is available in the <a href="http://docs.h2o.ai/h2o/latest-stable/h2o-docs/starting-h2o.html#from-the-command-line" rel="nofollow">H2O User Guide</a>.</p><p dir="auto"><a name="user-content-buildinghadoop"></a></p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">6. Building H2O on Hadoop</h2><a id="user-content-6-building-h2o-on-hadoop" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: 6. Building H2O on Hadoop" href="#6-building-h2o-on-hadoop"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">Pre-built H2O-on-Hadoop zip files are available on the <a href="http://h2o.ai/download" rel="nofollow">download page</a>.  Each Hadoop distribution version has a separate zip file in h2o-3.</p><p dir="auto">To build H2O with Hadoop support yourself, first install sphinx for python: <code>pip install sphinx</code>Then start the build by entering  the following from the top-level h2o-3 directory:</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="export BUILD_HADOOP=1;./gradlew build -x test;./gradlew dist;"><pre class="notranslate"><code>export BUILD_HADOOP=1;./gradlew build -x test;./gradlew dist;</code></pre></div><p dir="auto">This will create a directory called 'target' and generate zip files there.  Note that <code>BUILD_HADOOP</code> is the default behavior when the username is <code>jenkins</code> (refer to <code>settings.gradle</code>); otherwise you have to request it, as shown above.</p><p dir="auto">To build the zip files only for selected distributions use the <code>H2O_TARGET</code> env variable together with <code>BUILD_HADOOP</code>, for example:</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="export BUILD_HADOOP=1;export H2O_TARGET=hdp2.5,hdp2.6./gradlew build -x test;./gradlew dist;"><pre class="notranslate"><code>export BUILD_HADOOP=1;export H2O_TARGET=hdp2.5,hdp2.6./gradlew build -x test;./gradlew dist;</code></pre></div><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Adding support for a new version of Hadoop</h3><a id="user-content-adding-support-for-a-new-version-of-hadoop" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Adding support for a new version of Hadoop" href="#adding-support-for-a-new-version-of-hadoop"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">In the <code>h2o-hadoop</code> directory, each Hadoop version has a build directory for the driver and an assembly directory for the fatjar.</p><p dir="auto">You need to:</p><ol dir="auto"><li>Add a new driver directory and assembly directory (each with a <code>build.gradle</code> file) in <code>h2o-hadoop</code></li><li>Add these new projects to <code>h2o-3/settings.gradle</code></li><li>Add the new Hadoop version to <code>HADOOP_VERSIONS</code> in <code>make-dist.sh</code></li><li>Add the new Hadoop version to the list in <code>h2o-dist/buildinfo.json</code></li></ol><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Secure user impersonation</h3><a id="user-content-secure-user-impersonation" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Secure user impersonation" href="#secure-user-impersonation"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">Hadoop supports <a href="https://hadoop.apache.org/docs/r2.7.3/hadoop-project-dist/hadoop-common/Superusers.html" rel="nofollow">secure user impersonation</a> through its Java API.  A kerberos-authenticated user can be allowed to proxy any username that meets specified criteria entered in the NameNode's core-site.xml file.  This impersonation only applies to interactions with the Hadoop API or the APIs of Hadoop-related services that support it (this is not the same as switching to that user on the machine of origin).</p><p dir="auto">Setting up secure user impersonation (for h2o):</p><ol dir="auto"><li>Create or find an id to use as proxy which has limited-to-no access to HDFS or related services; the proxy user need only be used to impersonate a user</li><li>(Required if not using h2odriver) If you are not using the driver (e.g. you wrote your own code against h2o's API using Hadoop), make the necessary code changes to impersonate users (see <a href="http://hadoop.apache.org/docs/r2.8.0/api/org/apache/hadoop/security/UserGroupInformation.html" rel="nofollow">org.apache.hadoop.security.UserGroupInformation</a>)</li><li>In either of Ambari/Cloudera Manager or directly on the NameNode's core-site.xml file, add 2/3 properties for the user we wish to use as a proxy (replace  with the simple user name - not the fully-qualified principal name).<ul dir="auto"><li><code>hadoop.proxyuser.<proxyusername>.hosts</code>: the hosts the proxy user is allowed to perform impersonated actions on behalf of a valid user from</li><li><code>hadoop.proxyuser.<proxyusername>.groups</code>: the groups an impersonated user must belong to for impersonation to work with that proxy user</li><li><code>hadoop.proxyuser.<proxyusername>.users</code>: the users a proxy user is allowed to impersonate</li><li>Example: <code><property> <name>hadoop.proxyuser.myproxyuser.hosts</name> <value>host1,host2</value> </property> <property> <name>hadoop.proxyuser.myproxyuser.groups</name> <value>group1,group2</value> </property> <property> <name>hadoop.proxyuser.myproxyuser.users</name> <value>user1,user2</value> </property></code></li></ul></li><li>Restart core services such as HDFS & YARN for the changes to take effect</li></ol><p dir="auto">Impersonated HDFS actions can be viewed in the hdfs audit log ('auth:PROXY' should appear in the <code>ugi=</code> field in entries where this is applicable).  YARN similarly should show 'auth:PROXY' somewhere in the Resource Manager UI.</p><p dir="auto">To use secure impersonation with h2o's Hadoop driver:</p><p dir="auto"><em>Before this is attempted, see Risks with impersonation, below</em></p><p dir="auto">When using the h2odriver (e.g. when running with <code>hadoop jar ...</code>), specify <code>-principal <proxy user kerberos principal></code>, <code>-keytab <proxy user keytab path></code>, and <code>-run_as_user <hadoop username to impersonate></code>, in addition to any other arguments needed.  If the configuration was successful, the proxy user will log in and impersonate the <code>-run_as_user</code> as long as that user is allowed by either the users or groups configuration property (configured above); this is enforced by HDFS & YARN, not h2o's code.  The driver effectively sets its security context as the impersonated user so all supported Hadoop actions will be performed as that user (e.g. YARN, HDFS APIs support securely impersonated users, but others may not).</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h4 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Precautions to take when leveraging secure impersonation</h4><a id="user-content-precautions-to-take-when-leveraging-secure-impersonation" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Precautions to take when leveraging secure impersonation" href="#precautions-to-take-when-leveraging-secure-impersonation"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><ul dir="auto"><li>The target use case for secure impersonation is applications or services that pre-authenticate a user and then use (in this case) the h2odriver on behalf of that user.  H2O's Steam is a perfect example: auth user in web app over SSL, impersonate that user when creating the h2o YARN container.</li><li>The proxy user should have limited permissions in the Hadoop cluster; this means no permissions to access data or make API calls.  In this way, if it's compromised it would only have the power to impersonate a specific subset of the users in the cluster and only from specific machines.</li><li>Use the <code>hadoop.proxyuser.<proxyusername>.hosts</code> property whenever possible or practical.</li><li>Don't give the proxyusername's password or keytab to any user you don't want to impersonate another user (this is generally <em>any</em> user).  The point of impersonation is not to allow users to impersonate each other.  See the first bullet for the typical use case.</li><li>Limit user logon to the machine the proxying is occurring from whenever practical.</li><li>Make sure the keytab used to login the proxy user is properly secured and that users can't login as that id (via <code>su</code>, for instance)</li><li>Never set hadoop.proxyuser..{users,groups} to '*' or 'hdfs', 'yarn', etc.  Allowing any user to impersonate hdfs, yarn, or any other important user/group should be done with extreme caution and <em>strongly</em> analyzed before it's allowed.</li></ul><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h4 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Risks with secure impersonation</h4><a id="user-content-risks-with-secure-impersonation" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Risks with secure impersonation" href="#risks-with-secure-impersonation"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><ul dir="auto"><li>The id performing the impersonation can be compromised like any other user id.</li><li>Setting any <code>hadoop.proxyuser.<proxyusername>.{hosts,groups,users}</code> property to '*' can greatly increase exposure to security risk.</li><li>When users aren't authenticated before being used with the driver (e.g. like Steam does via a secure web app/API), auditability of the process/system is difficult.</li></ul><div Sparkling Water</h2><a id="user-content-7-sparkling-water" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: 7. Sparkling Water" href="#7-sparkling-water"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">Sparkling Water combines two open-source technologies: Apache Spark and the H2O Machine Learning platform.  It makes H2O’s library of advanced algorithms, including Deep Learning, GLM, GBM, K-Means, and Distributed Random Forest, accessible from Spark workflows. Spark users can select the best features from either platform to meet their Machine Learning needs.  Users can combine Spark's RDD API and Spark MLLib with H2O’s machine learning algorithms, or use H2O independently of Spark for the model building process and post-process the results in Spark.</p><p dir="auto"><strong>Sparkling Water Resources</strong>:</p><ul dir="auto"><li><a href="http://h2o.ai/download/" rel="nofollow">Download page for pre-built packages</a></li><li><a href="https://github.com/h2oai/sparkling-water">Sparkling Water GitHub repository</a></li><li><a href="https://github.com/h2oai/sparkling-water/blob/master/README.md">README</a></li><li><a href="https://github.com/h2oai/sparkling-water/blob/master/DEVEL.md">Developer documentation</a></li></ul><p dir="auto"><a name="user-content-documentation"></a></p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">8. Documentation</h2><a id="user-content-8-documentation" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: 8. Visit <a href="http://docs.h2o.ai" rel="nofollow">http://docs.h2o.ai</a> for the top-level introduction to documentation on H2O projects.</p><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Generate REST API documentation</h3><a id="user-content-generate-rest-api-documentation" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Generate REST API documentation" href="#generate-rest-api-documentation"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><p dir="auto">To generate the REST API documentation, use the following commands:</p><div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="cd ~/h2o-3cd pypython ./generate_rest_api_docs.py  #     H2O is an Open Source, Distributed, Fast & Scalable Machine Learning Platform: Deep Learning, Gradient Boosting (GBM) & XGBoost, Random Forest, Generalized Linear Modeling (GLM with Elastic Net),
